On the base they are attaching to, you made 4 nodes, something like this:

node_stack_connect1 = 1.005, 0.06, 0.0, 0.0, 1.0, 0.0, 0

node_stack_connect2 = -1.005, 0.06, 0.0, 0.0, 1.0, 0.0, 0

node_stack_connect3 = 0.0, 0.06, 1.005, 0.0, 1.0, 0.0, 0

node_stack_connect4 = 0.0, 0.06, -1.005, 0.0, 1.0, 0.0, 0

1 and 2 are on the far edges of the X axis, and 3 and 4 on the far edges of the Z axis, with the .06 being whatever you need 'height' wise.

Note that the extra zero on the end makes the nodes show up as the tiny pink ones instead of the bigger blue ones

Then add:

stackSymmetry = 3

which forces 4x symmetry (0 is 1x, 1 is 2x, 2 is 3x.. its a programmer thing)

Then set the first panel so it snaps onto one of the dots - use 4x and they should all snap on properly - if just the one does, then you need to move the nodes 'out' on the rim a little more. For instance on my example I started at 1.0 and -1.0 and had to keep tweaking... 1.005 finally worked.

If you have a collision node in that gap even without a visible 'mesh' then your panels will need to have a '1' in the last place of their attachment rules, which tells them to ignore collisions when attaching.

on the base with the 4 nodes, make sure they are oriented on the Y axis and arranged symmetrically on the surface, like so:

// definition format is Position X, Position Y, Position Z, Up X, Up Y, Up Z

node_stack_connect1 = 1.0, 0.06, 0.0, 0.0, 1.0, 0.0

node_stack_connect2 = -1.0, 0.06, 0.0, 0.0, 1.0, 0.0

node_stack_connect3 = 0.0, 0.06, 1.0, 0.0, 1.0, 0.0

node_stack_connect4 = 0.0, 0.06, -1.0, 0.0, 1.0, 0.0

note thata the 0.06 for Pos Y is just however much you need to raise the node to make it connectable (usually so that half of the blue orb is exposed) and that Y is 'UP' in KSP, so the top of a cylinder.

Then make your attachment rules something like this:

// attachment rules: stack, srfAttach, allowStack, allowSrfAttach, allowCollision

attachRules = 1,0,1,0,0

stackSymmetry = 3

stackSymmetry = 3 forces it to attach 4 pieces ( =0 is for 1, =1 is for 2, and =2 is for 3 pieces)

As long as your part will connect in the correct orientation in 1x symmetry, then it will now connect all 4 parts, rotated automatically, when it 4x mode.

If not, then you need to tweak the following on the connecting part:

attachRules = 1,0,1,0,1

specifically the last '1' - which lets parts connect even if their collision meshes are intersecting - if this lets them connect, this means your 4 top nodes need bigger spaces to let the collision nodes fit without colliding. (Or you can leave collision off and just adjust things to look right and forget about it)

The last 1 on attachRules is optional, if it works with it set to 1 but not zero, then your top nodes need to be spread out, because the colliders trying to attach to the 4 nodes are
